subject: RE: [junit] Need example JUnit tests to validate Test Mentor's support of JUnit
msgSnippet: Thanks. Distributed object support is scheduled for the next point release, which usually emerge roughly every four to eight weeks. We d definitely be
messageBody:
Thanks. Distributed object support is scheduled for the next point release,
which usually emerge roughly every four to eight weeks. We'd definitely be
interested in your tests for that. We use the Java Platform Debugger
Architecture (JPDA) to measure method coverage. It's pretty cool, but slows
down execution a bit, so its best to get timings separately with coverage
instrumentation turned off.


^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Erik Meade [mailto:emeade@...]
> Sent: Wednesday, March 07, 2001 11:36 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: RE: [junit] Need example JUnit tests to validate Test Mentor's
> support of JUnit
>
>
> Wow, pretty impressive looking tool.
>
> I did a find on your docs for ejb and servlet, came
> up with no matches, is it possible to measure code
> coverage of EJBs and Servlets? I couldn't find a whole
> lot on how the coverage works. You can run WebSphere
> and WebLogic in VisualAge... and I can come up with
> some sample EJB and servlet tests...
>
> --
> Erik Meade emeade@...
> Senior Consultant Object Mentor, Inc.
> http://www.junit.org
>
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: Michael Silverstein [mailto:msilverstein@...]
> > Sent: Wednesday, March 07, 2001 7:43 PM
> > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > Subject: RE: [junit] Need example JUnit tests to validate Test Mentor's
> > support of JUnit
> >
> >
> > Good idea and yes, we did start with the JUnit examples and samples and
> > other tests we had lying around. I was hoping for a little variety and
> > perhaps some unique and unanticipated usages of the JUnit framework.
> > Interestingly, I set up Test Mentor's code coverage piece to instrument
> > junit.* and ran the samples that come with JUnit through Test
> > Mentor and saw
> > that the junit.framework package is reasonably well tested (as far as
> > methods entered) by the examples that come with it. I threw together a
> > screen capture to illustrate at:
> > http://www.silvermark.com/evaluators/5.3result_junit.html
> >
> >
> > ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
> > Mike Silverstein, Lead Architect voice: (919) 858-8300 x29
> > SilverMark, Inc. fax: (919) 858-8308
> > 5511 Capital Center Drive mobile: (919) 669-5906
> > Suite 510, Raleigh, NC 27606 toll free: (888) 588-0668
> > http://www.silvermark.com msilverstein@...
> >
> > > -----Original Message-----
> > > From: Erik Meade [mailto:emeade@...]
> > > Sent: Wednesday, March 07, 2001 12:50 AM
> > > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > > Subject: RE: [junit] Need example JUnit tests to validate
> Test Mentor's
> > > support of JUnit
> > >
> > >
> > > Why not use the tests for JUnit itself as a start?
> > >
> > > --
> > > Erik Meade emeade@...
> > > Senior Consultant Object Mentor, Inc.
> > > http://www.junit.org
> > >
> > > > -----Original Message-----
> > > > From: Michael Silverstein [mailto:msilverstein@...]
> > > > Sent: Tuesday, March 06, 2001 1:01 PM
> > > > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > > > Subject: [junit] Need example JUnit tests to validate Test Mentor's
> > > > support of JUnit
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > SilverMark (www.silvermark.com) is currently preparing for
> > > release of its
> > > > extensions to Test Mentor  Java Edition to collaborate more
> > > closely with
> > > > JUnit. We are looking for existing tests that are written
> > for the JUnit
> > > > framework that we can incorporate into our own internal
> > > > regression tests, to
> > > > ensure that Test Mentor runs them correctly when executing
> > JUnit tests.
> > > > We've already tested with the samples that came with JUnit and a
> > > > few others
> > > > and are looking for more.
> > > >
> > > > Would anyone be willing to share some JUnit based tests (and
> > the classes
> > > > that they test), or point to some public domain tests, so we can
> > > > ensure Test
> > > > Mentor works correctly with JUnit under all circumstances?
> > > >
> > > > As an aside, if anyone is interested in trying out Test
> Mentor  Java
> > > > Edition with their own existing JUnit-based tests, they can sign
> > > > up for the
> > > > prerelease at:
> > > > http://www.silvermark.com/evaluators/5.3junit_releaseinfo.html.
> > > >
> > > > Test Mentor - Java edition is a commercial Java component
> > testing tool.
> > > > Skimming recent appends to this group, I noticed that Test
> > > Mentor supports
> > > > the following topics that were recently mentioned:
> > > >
> > > > - Transparently testing private methods
> > > > - Saving detailed test execution results to a file (XML).
> > > > - Driving tests from data files
> > > > - Parameterized tests
> > > > - User interface for selecting and running individual tests
> > > > within a suite
> > > >
> > > > Other immediate benefits of running your JUnit tests under
> Test Mentor
> > > > include:
> > > > - Automatic method coverage metrics
> > > > - Detailed assertion results reporting and fine-grained
> > timing metrics
> > > > - Automatic object interaction diagramming (to see which
> objects are
> > > > interacting as a result of a test)
> > > >
> > > > ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
